Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling returns home from school visibly upset after a difficult day with friends.
Situation2: They prepare a sermon for Sunday service to guide the congregation in moral decisions.
Story: I was sitting at my desk, Bible open, notes scattered, trying to shape my sermon for Sunday. The theme was forgiveness—how to let go of anger and choose compassion, even when it’s hard. I wanted to guide my congregation, to give them something real to hold onto. Just as I was finding the right words, I heard the front door slam. My younger brother trudged in, eyes red, backpack dragging. He didn’t say anything, just dropped onto the couch and stared at the floor. I knew something had happened at school—he’d been having trouble with his friends lately. As his sibling, I felt the pull to go to him, to listen, to be the shoulder he needed. But the sermon deadline pressed on me, and I wondered if I could pause my work. Was it right to set aside my pastoral duty, even for family? Or was this moment with my brother exactly what I was supposed to be living out, not just preaching? The expectations from both sides pressed in, and I sat there, torn, not sure which role needed me more.
